chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
If anyone leaves the Church after being baptized or is baptized outside the Church in the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit, and they are not restored to the Catholic Church before the end of their life, they will not escape death and will find no rest. During the time of the flood, anyone who did not enter Noah's ark, as stated in Genesis chapter seven, verse twenty-one, was not saved from the flood but perished, finding death instead of salvation in the water. The water, which prefigured the sacrament of baptism, lifted those in the ark from the earth to the heavens; but it killed those it found outside.

When Jericho was destroyed, Jesus ordered that everyone inside the house of Rahab the prostitute be saved unharmed, as stated in Joshua chapter six, verse twenty-five. But all others outside that house were consumed by destruction. The Church was prefigured in that ark and that house; but those who perished in the flood outside the ark, and those who died by the sword outside that house, represent a dual mystery. It seems appropriate to think that the flood signifies the baptism of Christian confession; so we may recognize that heretics, if they remain outside the Church, deserve punishment through baptism, not life, and those who deny Christ and leave the Catholic Church will face eternal punishment.

The blessed Peter explains the sacrament of the ark with these words: In the days when God's patience waited in the days of Noah, while the ark was being built, a few, that is, eight souls, were saved through water. This now saves you, too, through baptism of a similar form, not the removal of dirt from the body, but an appeal to God for a good conscience, as stated in First Peter chapter three, verses twenty and twenty-one. But where is a good conscience unless there is also unfeigned faith?

The apostle Paul teaches: The end of the commandment is love from a pure heart, a good conscience, and unfeigned faith, as stated in First Timothy chapter one, verse five. So why did the water of the flood not save those outside the ark, but kill them?
chunks.original_latin:
Caeterum si quis aut de Ecclesia baptizatus egreditur,
aut extra Ecclesiam in Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus
sancti nomine baptizatus, si ante finem praesentis
vitae non fuerit catholicae restitutus Ecclesiae, non
 carebit morte, sed requie: quia et tempore diluvii si
quis in arcam Noe (Genes VII 21) non est ingressus,
non est salvatus diluvio, sed necatus, nec salutem
invenit in aqua, sed mortem. Aqua quippe illa, in qua
praefigurabatur baptismatis sacramentum, quoscunque
in arca reperit, a terra suspensos ad coelestia sublimavit;
residuos autem oppressos occidit, quos
foris invenit. Et pereunte Hiericho, si quos domus
Raab meretricis inclusit, incolumes Jesus servare
praecepit (Josue VI 25); reliquos vero quos illa non
continebat domus, unius mortis consumpsit interitus. In illa igitur arca, et in illa domo una eademque
praefigurabatur Ecclesia; sed in his qui extra arcam
diluvio perierunt, et in eis qui extra illam domum
gladio mortui sunt, geminae significationis potest
 considerari mysterium. Existimo enim quantum mihi
nunc interim videtur, non incongrue credi in diluvii
significatione praecessisse baptisma Christianae confessionis;
ut agnoscamus haereticos, si extra Ecclesiam
permanserint, baptismo poenam mereri, non
vitam, et eos qui Christum negantes de Ecclesia catholica
discedunt, aeterno supplicio perituros. Arcae
quippe sacramentum beatus Petrus his verbis exponit:
In diebus quando exspectabat Dei patientia in diebus
Noe, cum fabricaretur arca, in qua pauci, id est
octo animae salvae factae sunt per aquam: quod et vos
nunc similis formae baptisma salvos facit, non carnis
depositio sordium, sed conscientiae bonae interrogatio
 in Deum (I Petr III 20 21). Ubi est autem conscientia
bona, nisi ubi est et fides non ficta? Docet
enim apostolus Paulus: Quia finis praecepti est caritas
de corde puro, et conscientia bona, et fide non ficta
(I Tim I 5). Quid ergo aqua diluvii non salvavit extra
arcam positos, sed occidit?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
<speak>
  Without a doubt, it foreshadows that every heretic, even if they have the sacrament of baptism, will be submerged in those waters leading to hell, while the ark is lifted up to heaven. <break time="500ms"/> They are destroyed by water because they are not within the ark's embrace, which is the only place where one can live and avoid perishing by the life-giving waters.
</speak>
chunks.original_latin:
Sine dubio praefigurabat
omnem haereticum, licet habentem baptismatis
sacramentum, non aliis, sed ipsis aquis ad inferna
mergendum, quibus arca sublevatur ad coelum. Neque
enim ob aliud eis interitus per aquam nascitur, nisi
quia eos arcae non continet sinus: in quo solo potest
vivere quisquis non vult aquis vitalibus interire.
